name: Berlin
intro_vibe: The Capital of Cool: Where history meets counterculture and the night never ends.

general_info.description: Berlin is not Germany—it is its own universe. A city of contrasts where bullet-scarred history meets hedonistic nightlife. From the freedom of Tempelhofer Feld to the grit of Neukölln, Berlin is raw, real, and unapologetically alternative.

weather_breakdown.name: December
pros: New Year's Eve at Brandenburg Gate

etiquette_tips: Cash is King: Berlin is oddly behind on tech. Bars, small shops, and late-night spots are often CASH ONLY. Always carry €50.
The Späti Culture: The 'Späti' (late-night corner store) is the center of social life. Grab a beer (€1.50) and sit on the bench outside. It is the Berlin way.
Club Rules: No photos. Ever. Put stickers on your phone camera. Dress casually (black helps), know the DJ, and don't be drunk in line.
Ticket Validation: There are no turnstiles, but plainclothes inspectors are ruthless. You MUST stamp your ticket in the little machine before boarding. Fine is €60.
Directness: Berliners are blunt. It's not rude, it's efficient. Don't expect fake smiles.
Bike Lanes are Lava: Do not walk in the bike lane. You will be shouted at or hit. Stay on the sidewalk.
Pfand System: Don't crush cans/bottles. They are worth €0.25. Leave them next to bins for collectors if you don't return them yourself.

neighborhoods.name: Kreuzberg
neighborhoods.description: The historic heart of West Berlin's counterculture. Turkish markets, punk bars, street art, and the canal. Gritty, real, and always awake.

neighborhoods.name: Neukölln
neighborhoods.description: The current cool kid. Rough around the edges but packed with trendy vegan cafes, dive bars, and Middle Eastern food. Young, messy, and fun.

neighborhoods.name: Friedrichshain
neighborhoods.description: Home to the legendary Berghain and the RAW-Gelände. Industrial, graffiti-covered, and hedonistic. Where the weekend never ends.

neighborhoods.name: Mitte
neighborhoods.description: Berlin's polished center. Museums, landmarks, and upscale shopping. Touristy, but essential for the 'Checklist' sights.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
logistics.summary: Essential friction-removers for a smooth trip.
details: Sundays: almost EVERYTHING is closed (shops, supermarkets). Only restaurants and museums are open. Plan accordingly.
Jaywalking: Don't do it. Germans wait for the green man (Ampelmann). Crossing on red is socially judged.
Water: Tap water is safe but restaurants charge for bottled. Ask for 'Leitungswasser' (tap) but prepared for a 'no'.
Tipping: Round up the bill (e.g., make €9.20 into €10). Tell the waiter the total amount you want to pay *before* they charge you.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The U-Bahn (Metro) and S-Bahn (Train) are your lifelines. Runs 24/7 on weekends.
details: U-Bahn: Yellow trains, mostly underground. Fast and frequent.
S-Bahn: Red/Yellow trains, mostly above ground. Great for longer distances.
Tickets: Buy a 'Zone AB' ticket for the city center. VALIDATE IT by stamping it in the box on the platform.
Apps: Use 'BVG Fahrinfo' or Google Maps. They are accurate.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Berlin is safe, but has rough edges.
details: Görlitzer Park: Known for drug dealers. It's generally safe to walk through during the day, but avoid at night.
Pickpockets: Active on crowded tourist lines (U2, U8) and at Alexanderplatz.
Bike Theft: Extremely common. Never leave a bike unlocked, even for a minute.

must_eat.description: Berlin's #1 street food. Invented here (not Turkey). Crispy meat, fresh salad, and garlic sauce in toasted bread. Don't wait 2 hours for Mustafa's—your neighborhood spot is likely just as good.
Steamed then fried pork sausage cut into slices and drowned in curry ketchup and powder. Served with fries or a bread roll. A cult classic.
Berlin has a massive Vietnamese community. The Pho, Banh Mi, and Bun Cha here are some of the best in Europe. Look for 'Monsieur Vuong' or holes-in-the-wall in Mitte/Prenzlauer Berg.
Huge, cheap, and delicious. Crispy falafel, hummus, halloumi, and roasted veggies. A staple of Kreuzberg and Neukölln diets.
The fuel of Berlin. A caffeinated, sparkling yerba mate tea. Tastes like cigarette ash the first time, but you'll be addicted by the third bottle.
German bread is world-class. Grab a 'Belegtes Brötchen' (sandwich) or a 'Laugenbrezel' (pretzel) for a cheap breakfast.
Breaded, fried cutlet (pork or veal). Best enjoyed in a traditional Wirtshaus with potato salad and a cold beer.
It's Bavarian, not Berliner, and very touristy. But if you want the giant 1-liter beers and Oompah music experience, this is where you go.

items.description: An abandoned airport turned into a massive public park. Locals skate on the runways, BBQ, and fly kites. The ultimate symbol of Berlin's freedom.
Skip the expensive bar. Buy a €1.50 beer from a corner store (Späti), sit on the bench outside, and watch the city go by.
A Sunday ritual. Huge flea market followed by public 'Bearpit Karaoke' where thousands cheer on strangers singing.
The symbol of reunification. Best viewed at night when fewer crowds are present. Walk through it to feel the history.
The longest remaining stretch of the Berlin Wall, covered in murals. It's an open-air gallery, free to walk.
A haunting field of 2,711 concrete slabs. Walking into the center is disorienting and powerful. Please remain respectful (no selfies on the blocks).
Abandoned NSA listening station on a hill made of WWII rubble. Covered in graffiti with incredible city views. A bit of a hike.
Located in the former HQ of the East German secret police. A chilling look at surveillance and control.
UNESCO World Heritage site with five world-renowned museums including the Pergamon (check for closures) and Neues Museum.

affiliate_products.title: European Travel Adapter (Type F)
affiliate_products.reason: German plugs are Type F (two round pins). Essential for charging your devices.

affiliate_products.title: Cash Wallet
affiliate_products.reason: Berlin is a cash city. You will need a wallet that can hold coins and bills comfortably.

affiliate_products.title: Portable Charger
affiliate_products.reason: Long nights out and navigating the U-Bahn drain batteries fast. Stay connected.
